1.title: The Social Scaffold
1.description: The foundation. Greetings, yes/no, respect toggles, basic existence and commands.

episodes.intro: Today we build the foundation. The four words you need to survive. Hello, Yes, No, and Okay.
episodes.scenario: You meet a neighbor. He asks if you are new. You say Yes. He asks if you need help. You say No. He says Okay. You say Hello.

episodes.intro: Tamil society runs on hierarchy. Today we learn how to show respect without thinking: the Peer vs. Elder dynamic.
episodes.scenario: You meet your younger cousin. You use 'Nee'. Then her father walks in. You switch to 'Neenga' instantly. Architect Note: Channel Sathyaraj's smooth transition between casual and respectful tones here.

episodes.intro: Today we answer the big questions. Where is it? And does it exist?
episodes.scenario: You are looking for your phone. You ask 'Where?'. Your wife says 'It is here'. You ask again. Wife says 'Don't know'.

episodes.intro: Moving yourself and your desires. I want. I go. I come.
episodes.scenario: You want coffee. Coffee Venum. You are leaving for work. Poren. You point to the remote. 'Kudunga' (Give).

episodes.intro: The first Boss Fight. Putting it all together in the Living Room.
episodes.scenario: Full simulation. Greeting elders, accepting coffee, refusing snacks, and finding the remote.

episodes.intro: The Audit. We review the first words. No new concepts. Just pure muscle memory.
episodes.scenario: Rapid fire audit. I say the English, you say the Tamil immediately.

episodes.intro: The art of politeness. We focus on the suffix 'Nga' and the tone of 'Sari'.
episodes.scenario: You are hosting. You ask guests to sit. You ask if they ate. You listen to them speak and say 'Sari' to show respect.

2.title: Domestic Defense
2.description: The Kitchen. Surviving meals, managing time, expressing internal states, and the art of hospitality.

episodes.intro: Week 2. The Kitchen. The most dangerous room in the house. Today we learn how to survive by giving feedback.
episodes.scenario: You are eating. The host looks at you. You say 'Super'. They give you pickle. You say 'Kaaram'. They ask about the rice. You say 'Nalla Irukku'.

episodes.intro: They want you to do things now. You want to do them later. Today we control time.
episodes.scenario: Mother-in-law asks you to fix the fan. You say 'Not now. Later.' She asks when. You say 'Tomorrow'. She says 'Okay'.

episodes.intro: Managing the flow of food. The 'Infinite Dosa' loop is real. You need shields.
episodes.scenario: They bring rice. You say 'Konjam'. They bring a bucket of Sambar. You say 'Podhum!'. They offer a sweet. You say 'Onnu Mattum'.

episodes.intro: How do you feel? Hunger, thirst, and fatigue. And the 'To me / To you' pattern.
episodes.scenario: You come home. Wife asks 'Coffee?'. You say 'No, Thirst'. She gives water. She asks 'Food?'. You say 'Enaku Pasi' (To me hunger).

episodes.intro: The Ultimate Test. You are seated. The leaf is open. Survive.
episodes.scenario: Rice is served. Say 'Enough'. Sambar is poured. Say 'Super'. They offer seconds. Say 'Only one'. They ask if you want Rasam. Say 'Later'. You finish. Say 'Stomach Full'.

episodes.intro: Audit day. Reviewing the Kitchen Arsenal.
episodes.scenario: Rapid fire. English to Tamil.

episodes.intro: The Art of Hospitality. You cannot just say No. You must praise, then refuse.
episodes.scenario: You are leaving a dinner. You say the food was Super. You say 'Poittu Varen'. They say stay longer. You say 'Paravailla'.

3.title: Urban Survival
3.description: The Streets. Auto rickshaws, numbers, money, and spatial relationships.

episodes.intro: You are no longer in the house. You are in an Auto Rickshaw. You must command the pilot.
episodes.scenario: You are in an auto. You see your street. You say 'Right'. Then 'Left'. Then 'Stop here'.

episodes.intro: Commerce. You cannot buy if you cannot count. The essential numbers for survival.
episodes.scenario: You ask for 2 idlis. Rendu. Price is 10 rupees. Pathu. Give 100 rupees. Nooru.

episodes.intro: Money. How to ask the price and complain that it is too high.
episodes.scenario: You buy bananas. You ask 'How much?'. He says 500. You say 'Too much'. You ask 'Less?'.

episodes.intro: Where exactly is it? Spatial relationships and prepositions of place.
episodes.scenario: Phone is inside the bag. Bag is on the table. Key is with me.

episodes.intro: The Market. You need to take an auto to the market and buy fruit. Fight.
episodes.scenario: Auto Driver asks where. Say 'Go Straight'. You need to turn. Say 'Right'. You reach the shop. Say 'Stop'. You pick an apple. Ask 'How much?'. He says 1000 rupees. Say 'Too much!'. Ask for 'Less'.

episodes.intro: Audit Day. Reviewing direction and money.
episodes.scenario: Rapid fire.

episodes.intro: The Meter. The classic conflict. Negotiating the ride.
episodes.scenario: You get in. You say 'Meter Podunga'. He says No. You say 'Polaam' (Let's go). At the end, you ask for 'Chillarai'.

4.title: The Debrief
4.description: Past tense. Reporting what happened with chronology, sequence, and logic connectors.

episodes.intro: You are no longer in the present. You must report what happened. Today we learn the past tense for movement and action.
episodes.scenario: Wife asks what you did today. You say 'I went to the market. I came back. I gave the money'.

episodes.intro: What did you consume? Food, media, sleep. The past tense of consumption.
episodes.scenario: You woke up. You drank coffee. You ate breakfast. You watched TV. You slept.

episodes.intro: Building sequences. First this, then that. Before, after, yesterday, today.
episodes.scenario: Yesterday I went to the market. First I bought rice. After that I came home. Today I am tired.

episodes.intro: Why did it happen? Because. Therefore. But. The glue that makes stories make sense.
episodes.scenario: I was hungry. Therefore I went to the shop. But the shop was closed. That's why I came home.

episodes.intro: The family is seated. They want to know about your day. Tell them 4 sequential things you did.
episodes.scenario: What did you do first? 'First I went to office.' After that? 'After that I did a meeting.' Then? 'Then I ate lunch.' Why did you come home late? 'Traffic was too much, therefore it got late.'

episodes.intro: Audit Day. Reviewing the past tense and chronology glue.
episodes.scenario: Rapid fire drill. Build three-sentence stories using past tense and connectors.

episodes.intro: The infinite care question. Understanding why 'Did you eat?' is never just about food.
episodes.scenario: Someone calls you at 3pm. First question: Saaptingala? You must answer correctly or they will worry.

5.title: Kinship & Gossip
5.description: Family structure. Pronouns, reported speech, opinions, and the gossip protocol.

episodes.intro: Family structure. You must know who everyone is. The kinship system is not negotiable.
episodes.scenario: Someone introduces their family. You must identify: Who is Anna? Who is Thambi? Who is the Mama?

episodes.intro: They, he, she, it. Understanding the pronoun system and when to use plural for respect.
episodes.scenario: Talking about your boss. You say 'Avanga' (respectful). Talking about your nephew. You say 'Avan'. Talking about your family to in-laws. You say 'Naanga'.

episodes.intro: He said, she said. The gossip protocol. Reporting what others told you.
episodes.scenario: Anna asked where you went. You said you went to the market. He said it was too far.

episodes.intro: The opinion layer. I think, I know, I don't know, Really?
episodes.scenario: Someone tells you Anna got a new job. You say 'Really?'. They ask if you knew. You say 'I didn't understand'. You say 'I thought he was happy at his old job'.

episodes.intro: The living room. Multiple relatives. Someone starts talking about someone who is not present. You must track and report.
episodes.scenario: Akka asks if you know about Mama's new house. You say 'I don't know. What did they say?'. She says Mama said it's very big. You say 'Is that so? Really?'. She asks if you will visit. You say 'I thought I would go next week'.

episodes.intro: Audit Day. Reviewing kinship terms and pronoun toggles.
episodes.scenario: Rapid fire. Practice constructing gossip chains: X told Y who told Z.

episodes.intro: The cousin marriage system. Understanding why your cousin is also your potential spouse.
episodes.scenario: Understanding family structure conversations. When they say 'Murai Maman's daughter', they might be matchmaking.

episodes.intro: The casual tier. Hanging out with peers and cousins. Dropping the formalities and embracing the Kongu vibe.
episodes.scenario: You are at a tea stall with your cousins. You call your male cousin over. You ask him what's up using Kongu slang. Architect Note: Inject some Goundamani-style friendly sarcasm here.

episodes.intro: The soft tier. How to talk to children affectionately using the gentle 'nga' suffix and sweet names.
episodes.scenario: Your niece is running around. You call her over affectionately. You give her a sweet. She is naughty, so you tell her to be still gently. Architect Note: Channel Sivakumar's soft, paternal movie persona here.

6.title: Operations (The Future)
6.description: Future tense. Planning, proposing, scheduling, and conditional logic.

episodes.intro: You are no longer reporting the past. You are declaring intent. I will go. I will come. I will do.
episodes.scenario: Wife asks your plans. You say 'I will go to the market. I will come back. I will eat dinner'.

episodes.intro: Shall we? Should we? The proposal forms. Inviting action.
episodes.scenario: Friend asks 'Shall we go to the movie?'. You say 'Let's go'. He asks 'Shall we eat first?'. You agree.

episodes.intro: When will it happen? Tomorrow, next week, always, sometimes.
episodes.scenario: Boss asks when you will finish the report. You say 'Tomorrow'. He asks if you always work late. You say 'Sometimes'.

episodes.intro: If this, then that. The conditional logic. If you come, if it rains, if he goes.
episodes.scenario: Wife says 'If it rains, don't go'. You say 'If I have time, I will come early'.

episodes.intro: Planning a social outing with contingencies. You must propose a plan with two backup options.
episodes.scenario: Propose going to the beach. What if it rains? Go to the mall. When shall we go? Tomorrow morning. What if there is no time? We can see next week.

episodes.intro: Audit Day. Reviewing future tense and conditional logic.
episodes.scenario: Rapid fire. Build conditional sentences with future plans.

episodes.intro: Understanding Tamil time. Why 'I'm coming' means 'I haven't left yet'.
episodes.scenario: Understanding the progression: Varren (still at home) → Kilambitten (in transit) → Vandhutten (arrived). Learn to decode actual arrival time.

7.title: Local Fluency (Attitude)
7.description: Sentence tags, intensifiers, fillers, speech compression. Sounding local, not textbook.

episodes.intro: Attitude and Flow. You sound like a textbook. Today we add the local flavor. Question tags that make you sound native.
episodes.scenario: You say 'The movie was good, right?'. You say 'You are coming, right?'. Someone mumbles. You say 'What?'.

episodes.intro: Making things extreme. Super becomes Semma. Bad becomes Mokkai. The intensifier layer.
episodes.scenario: Friend asks about the food. You say 'Semma!'. He asks about the movie. You say 'Mokkai'. The cricket match was 'Vera level'.

episodes.intro: The pause words. The thinking sounds. Making your Tamil sound natural, not rehearsed.
episodes.scenario: Someone asks a question. You say 'One minute'. You think. You say 'Actually, I was just casually thinking about it. And then I forgot'.

episodes.intro: The compression layer. How fast speech changes the words.
episodes.scenario: Practice saying both versions. Understand that locals use the compressed form. You should recognize both.

episodes.intro: Your friend asks about the movie you watched. Describe it using only intensifiers and fillers. No plain adjectives allowed.
episodes.scenario: How was the movie? 'Actually it was an awesome movie. Next level.' Was the story good? 'The story was simply super.' What about the villain? 'Villain was extreme. He acted fantastically.' Will you watch it again? 'Exactly, I thought I should watch it again tomorrow itself.'

episodes.intro: Audit Day. Reviewing slang, intensifiers, and fillers.
episodes.scenario: Rapid fire. Take simple sentences and add intensifiers and fillers to make them sound natural.

episodes.intro: The dialect of Coimbatore. Understanding the Kongu slang overlay.
episodes.scenario: Understanding the Kovai street dialect. How formality drops among friends. When to use Machi and when to avoid Dey.

8.title: Deep Cover (Graduation)
8.description: Conflict resolution, humor, adverbs of manner, and full synthesis. The final level.

episodes.intro: Conflict resolution. Apology. Confrontation. The hard conversations.
episodes.scenario: Someone is upset. You ask 'What happened?'. They complain. You say 'Leave it. It's okay'.

episodes.intro: Making people laugh. Understanding jokes. The humor vocabulary.
episodes.scenario: Someone makes a joke. You laugh and say 'Sema joke!'. They ask if you're making fun. You say 'Nothing, just fun'.

episodes.intro: How did it happen? Fast, slow, carefully. The manner layer.
episodes.scenario: Auto driver is going fast. You say 'Slowly!'. Mother gives you hot food. She says 'Carefully!'.

episodes.intro: Combining everything from Levels 1-7. No new vocabulary. Pure synthesis.
episodes.scenario: Complex scenarios requiring vocabulary from multiple levels. Simulate a full day: Morning greeting → Breakfast feedback → Auto ride → Market shopping → Evening report → Gossip session → Future planning.

episodes.intro: The final Boss Fight. A 5-minute conversation with zero English connectors. You must use only Tamil.
episodes.scenario: Friend calls. Greet them. They ask what you did yesterday. Tell a full story. They propose going to a movie tomorrow. Discuss options. End the call properly.

episodes.intro: Full Survival Run. Simulating a complete day in Tamil. From waking up to going to bed. All in Tamil.
episodes.scenario: Morning: Wake up, greet family, breakfast conversation. Mid-morning: Call to confirm appointment, give directions. Afternoon: Market shopping, price negotiation, auto ride. Evening: Report your day to family, discuss plans. Night: Social call with friend, movie review, plan weekend.

episodes.intro: You made it. You are no longer a beginner. You are an Embedded Local.
episodes.scenario: Someone asks if you speak Tamil. You smile. You say 'I'm learning little by little'. They are impressed. You have arrived.

9.title: The Interrogator
9.description: The complete question toolkit. Missing question words, ability, permission, and obligation grammar.

episodes.intro: You can say things. But you cannot ASK things. Today we fix that. Three question words that unlock every conversation.
episodes.scenario: Mother-in-law is on the phone. She hangs up. You ask 'Who called?'. She says Anna. You ask 'Why?'. She says he's coming. You ask 'When?'. She says tomorrow.

episodes.intro: How does it work? Which one do you want? The two question words that let you navigate any process.
episodes.scenario: You want to make filter coffee. You ask 'How?'. Mother-in-law explains. She asks 'Which coffee powder?'. You don't know. She asks 'How much water?'. You guess wrong.

episodes.intro: Ability. The most important grammar you are missing. Can you do it? Or can you not? This changes everything.
episodes.scenario: Mother-in-law asks if you can fix the mixer. You say 'Mudiyaadhu' (I can't). She asks if you can call the repair guy. You say 'Mudiyum' (I can). She asks if you can come early tomorrow. You say 'Mudiyum'.

episodes.intro: Must do. Must not do. The obligation layer. The grammar that every household runs on.
episodes.scenario: House rules. You must eat before leaving. You must call when you arrive. You must not wear shoes inside. You must not skip dinner.

episodes.intro: A mystery object. You have five questions. Each must use a different question word. Solve it.
episodes.scenario: What is it? Where is it? Who gave it? When did it come? Why is it here? How does it work? Which one is it? Use questions to solve the mystery.

episodes.intro: Audit Day. Drilling the question words and ability grammar.
episodes.scenario: Rapid fire. I describe a situation, you ask the right question word.

episodes.intro: Questions are not just information. They are love. Understanding why 'Who called?' is care, not nosiness.
episodes.scenario: Your wife comes home looking upset. You ask 'What happened?'. She says Anna called. You ask 'Who called exactly?'. She says Mama. You ask 'Where did he go?'. Every question is a hug.

10.title: The Emotional Radar
10.description: Feelings, emotions, likes and dislikes. Moving from physical states to emotional literacy.

episodes.intro: You can say you are hungry. You can say you are tired. But can you say you are HAPPY? Feelings start today.
episodes.scenario: Your child says their first Tamil word. Wife says 'I'm so happy!'. Grandma says 'I feel proud'. You feel both.

episodes.intro: The dark side. Anger when the auto cheats you. Fear when you see the cockroach. Essential survival emotions.
episodes.scenario: Auto driver charges double. You feel angry. Wife says 'Don't be angry'. You see a huge cockroach in the bathroom. Now you feel fear. Wife laughs.

episodes.intro: The quiet emotions. The ones that sit in the chest. Worry when Mom calls from abroad. Sadness when friends leave.
episodes.scenario: Mom calls from abroad. She worries about you. You say 'Don't worry'. Friend is leaving Coimbatore. You feel sad. At a family function, someone praises your Tamil. You feel shy.

episodes.intro: The preference system. This is how you build a personality in Tamil. I like this. I don't like that.
episodes.scenario: Friend asks about food. You like dosa. You don't like bitter gourd. Wife's preference is biryani. What is your favorite movie? 'I like Rajini movies'.

episodes.intro: A movie scene described to you. Identify and express four different emotions as the scene unfolds.
episodes.scenario: Scene: Hero gets a promotion (happy). Villain threatens his family (fear). His friend betrays him (angry). His mother is alone at home (worry). Express each emotion as you hear the story.

episodes.intro: Audit Day. The emotion vocabulary drill.
episodes.scenario: Rapid fire. I describe a situation, you name the emotion.

episodes.intro: Emotions in Tamil don't happen TO you. They happen FOR you. The 'Enakku + emotion' pattern that unlocks all feelings.

vocab.english: I am happy (lit: to me, joy)
I am scared (lit: to me, it is fearful)
I am worried (lit: to me, it is worrisome)

episodes.scenario: Understanding the dative pattern. English says 'I am happy'. Tamil says 'To me, happiness exists'. This pattern works for ALL emotions and is the key to sounding natural.

11.title: The Adjective Arsenal
11.description: Descriptors. Size, quality, temperature, newness, comparison. The ability to describe anything you see.

episodes.intro: You can say what happened and how you felt. Can you describe what it LOOKS like? Today: size.
episodes.scenario: Family function. Describing relatives. Mama is tall. His son is short. Anna's new house is big. The guest room is small.

episodes.intro: The age of things. New car. Old house. Beautiful temple. These adjectives unlock real description.
episodes.scenario: House hunting. This flat is new. That building is old. The balcony view is beautiful. Shall we see the new one or the old one?

episodes.intro: Quality judgments. Good food. Bad traffic. Wrong turn. Right answer. The opinion layer.
episodes.scenario: Restaurant review with friend. Good food. Bad service. They gave the wrong order. But the bill was correct. Good place or bad place?

episodes.intro: How does it feel? Hot weather. Cold AC. Difficult language. Easy task.
episodes.scenario: Coimbatore summer. Outside is hot. Inside the AC room is cold. Learning Tamil grammar is difficult. But speaking is easy. The coffee is too hot. Wait.

episodes.intro: I describe a scene. You must use at least 5 different adjectives to describe what you see.
episodes.scenario: You are at Marina Beach in the evening. Describe: the sand (hot), the water (cold), the crowd (big), the sunset (beautiful), finding parking (difficult), the snacks (good). Paint the picture in Tamil.

episodes.intro: Audit Day. Drilling adjectives across all categories.
episodes.scenario: Rapid fire. I say a noun, you give the best adjective.

episodes.intro: He is taller THAN me. This is better THAN that. The comparison marker 'vida' that lets you rank the world.
episodes.scenario: Comparing two restaurants. This one is better than that. That one is bigger than this. The food here is hotter than there. Using 'vida' to compare anything.

12.title: The Morning Protocol
12.description: Daily routine. Wake up, bathe, dress, navigate the house, leave and return. The domestic verb layer.

episodes.intro: Every day starts the same way. Get up. Brush. Bathe. The routine verbs that structure your morning.
episodes.scenario: Wife shouts 'Get up! It's late!'. You stumble to the bathroom. 'Did you brush?'. Not yet. 'Brush first, then bathe'. The morning sequence is non-negotiable.

episodes.intro: What you wear matters. Especially for temple. The clothing verbs and the negotiation of what to put on.
episodes.scenario: Going to temple. Wife says 'Change your shirt'. You're wearing the wrong color. Take it off. Put on the white one. 'Change your clothes properly'.

episodes.intro: Navigating the physical space. Doors, windows, fans, lights. The commands that control your environment.
episodes.scenario: Summer afternoon. 'Close the door'. 'Open the window'. 'Turn on the fan'. Night time. 'Turn off the light'. Guest is coming. 'Open the door'. Someone left the fan on. 'Turn off the fan'.

episodes.intro: Leaving the house and coming back. The verbs that bookend every day.
episodes.scenario: Morning rush. 'I'm leaving!'. Wife calls 'When will you return?'. Evening: 'It's late, leave the office'. You get home. 'I've returned'. 'Why so late?'.

episodes.intro: Narrate your entire morning from alarm to departure. Use only Tamil.
episodes.scenario: 6:30am. Wake up. Brush teeth. Bathe. Choose clothes. Put on shirt. Open the door. Fan is on. Close the window. 'I'm leaving!'. 'It's late!'. Go.

episodes.intro: Audit Day. Morning routine vocabulary drill.
episodes.scenario: Rapid fire. I describe the action, you give the Tamil verb.

episodes.intro: Why the doorstep matters. The kolam is drawn every morning. Understanding this daily ritual connects you to the rhythm of the house.
episodes.scenario: You wake up early. Grandmother is already at the doorstep drawing kolam. Every morning. Without fail. She asks if you want to learn. You say 'How do you do it?'. She says 'You must do it every morning'.

13.title: Kitchen Commander
13.description: Cooking, cleaning, and commanding the kitchen. The domestic verb layer that makes you useful.

episodes.intro: You survived the kitchen in Level 2. Now you must RUN it. Today: the action verbs of cooking.
episodes.scenario: Mother-in-law is cooking. 'Stir the sambar'. 'Pour the water'. 'I'll cook the rice'. You help. She is impressed. Slightly.

episodes.intro: Three verbs that control every object in the house. Open the fridge. Close the door. Keep it there.
episodes.scenario: 'Open the fridge. Take the milk. Close the door. Keep the plate on the table.' Simple commands. But now you understand them AND can say them.

episodes.intro: After cooking comes cleaning. Three different verbs for three different kinds of washing.
episodes.scenario: After lunch. Wash the plates. Wipe the table. There's a stain on your shirt. Wash it. No, not wash like dishes — wash like clothes. Different verb.

episodes.intro: The nouns you hear fifteen times a day. Water. Rice. Milk. Coffee. Tea.
episodes.scenario: Morning list. We need water. Do we have rice? Buy milk. Make coffee. Or do you want tea? The kitchen runs on these five nouns.

episodes.intro: It is Sunday. Full traditional lunch is being prepared. You must help. Follow every instruction.
episodes.scenario: Open the fridge. Take the vegetables. Wash them. Pour water in the pot. Stir the sambar. Keep the plates on the table. Close the kitchen door. Wipe the counter. Make coffee.

episodes.intro: Audit Day. Kitchen verbs and nouns.
episodes.scenario: Rapid fire. I describe the kitchen action, you give the Tamil verb.

episodes.intro: Filter coffee is not a beverage. It is a religion. Understanding the ritual, the vocabulary, and why 'degree coffee' means something very specific.
episodes.scenario: The process. Boil the milk. Add the decoction. Pour between tumbler and davara. The sound. The foam. The first sip. Understanding why 'how many degrees?' is a coffee question.

14.title: The Digital Connector
14.description: Phone calls, messaging, making plans, confirming and cancelling. Social connection through technology.

episodes.intro: The phone is how Tamil families stay connected. Calling someone and answering the phone — the first digital verbs.
episodes.scenario: 'Call Anna'. You call. He's not picking up. 'Call again'. He picks up. 'Who called?'. 'I called'. The phone conversation loop.

episodes.intro: Messages. Photos. The digital exchange. Send it. Did you get it?
episodes.scenario: 'Send the photo on WhatsApp'. 'Did you get my message?'. 'Yes, I received it'. 'Send it to Akka also'. 'I already sent it'.

episodes.intro: Before you make a plan, you must check availability. Are you free? Do you have time? Are you ready?
episodes.scenario: Planning a weekend outing. 'Are you free Saturday?'. Friend says 'I don't have time'. You ask another friend. 'Ready to go?'. 'Give me 5 minutes'.

episodes.intro: Plans change. The ability to confirm, cancel, and reschedule is pure social survival.
episodes.scenario: The plan changes three times. 'Confirmed for Saturday'. Rain forecast. 'Cancel the beach'. 'Postpone to Sunday'. Finally: 'Confirmed. Sunday morning. Be ready'.

episodes.intro: Coordinate meeting 3 people for dinner. Call each one. Check availability. Confirm or reschedule.
episodes.scenario: Call Friend 1. Free Saturday? Yes. Call Friend 2. Not free Saturday, postpone to Sunday? Call Friend 1 again. Sunday okay? Confirmed. Send message to all: 'Sunday 7pm. Be ready'.

episodes.intro: Audit Day. Phone and planning vocabulary.
episodes.scenario: Rapid fire. I describe a communication scenario, you give the right Tamil phrase.

episodes.intro: How Tamil looks in text messages. The abbreviations. The emoji culture. Understanding digital Tamil.
episodes.scenario: Reading a WhatsApp group chat. Understanding how spoken Tamil becomes text Tamil. The voice note culture. Why Tamils send 47 voice notes instead of one text.

15.title: The Verb Engine: Action
15.description: Systematic verb paradigm training. Five high-frequency action verbs across all tenses, wrapped in scenarios.

episodes.intro: The verb you hear most in any conversation ABOUT conversations. I'm speaking. I spoke. I will speak. Speak!
episodes.scenario: 'Who are you talking to?'. 'I was speaking to Anna'. 'Don't speak so loudly'. 'Speak in Tamil'. 'I will speak to him tomorrow'. Every form in a family argument.

episodes.intro: The market verb. You need it every single day. What did you buy? What should I buy? Buy this!
episodes.scenario: 'What are you buying?'. 'I bought vegetables'. 'Buy two kilos of rice'. 'I will buy milk tomorrow'. The daily shopping conversation.

episodes.intro: You lose things. Everyone loses things. The verb for searching is your daily companion.
episodes.scenario: 'I'm searching for my keys'. 'I searched everywhere'. 'Search under the sofa'. 'I'll search in the car'. The daily hunt for lost objects.

episodes.intro: Movement at two speeds. The physical action verbs. Walk slowly. Run fast. Don't run in the house!
episodes.scenario: 'Walk slowly'. 'I walked to the shop yesterday'. 'The bus is coming — run!'. 'Don't run in the house!'. 'He ran very fast'. Two verbs, two speeds, all tenses.

episodes.topic: BOSS FIGHT: The Full Day in Verbs
episodes.intro: Narrate a complete day using all verb families from this level and previous levels.
episodes.scenario: Morning: I spoke to wife. I walked to the bus stop. I ran because the bus came. Afternoon: I searched for the file. I bought lunch. Evening: Speaking to friend. Walking home. Full paradigm usage.

episodes.intro: Audit Day. All verb paradigms from this level.
episodes.scenario: Rapid fire. I say the English tense, you give the Tamil conjugation. Present. Past. Future. Command.

episodes.intro: The secret pattern. Add the infinitive to Venum, Mudiyum, or Kudaadhu and you can express any desire, ability, or prohibition.
episodes.scenario: Combining verbs. 'I need to go'. 'I can't eat now'. 'You shouldn't speak loudly'. 'I'm going to buy vegetables'. The infinitive is the key that chains all verbs together.

16.title: The Verb Engine: Mind & Hand
16.description: Mental and physical verbs. Forget, learn, show, hit, let go. The verbs of cognition and physical interaction.

episodes.intro: The most honest verb. Everyone forgets. Keys. Birthdays. Promises. Today we learn how to confess it.
episodes.scenario: 'I forgot the keys!'. Wife says 'Don't forget to call Mama'. You promise. Next day: 'Did you call?'. 'I forgot again'. 'Some things you cannot forget!'.

episodes.intro: The verb that describes your entire journey. I am learning. I learned. How did you learn? The meta-language verb.
episodes.scenario: Someone asks 'Do you know Tamil?'. 'I'm learning'. 'How did you learn?'. 'I learned from my wife'. 'You must learn more!'. 'I will learn'. The verb about the journey itself.

episodes.intro: Show me. I'll show you. He showed the way. The verb of demonstration and revelation.
episodes.scenario: 'Show me the way to the temple'. 'I showed him the photo'. 'I'll show you the shop tomorrow'. 'Let me show you how to make filter coffee'. Showing is teaching.

episodes.intro: Two verbs with massive range. Hit, beat, strike. And also: let, leave, release. Opposites that define Tamil life.
episodes.scenario: Kids fighting. 'Don't hit your brother!'. Cricket match. 'He hit a six!'. Argument escalates. 'Leave it'. 'Let him go'. Two verbs that contain all of Tamil drama.

episodes.intro: Rapid scenario switching. Every scene needs a different verb family. No thinking time.
episodes.scenario: You forgot your bag. Search for it. Someone calls — pick up. They ask what happened. You show them the empty table. Learn from this mistake. Let it go. Next scene. Don't stop.

episodes.intro: Audit Day. All cognitive and physical verb paradigms.
episodes.scenario: Rapid fire paradigm drill. Present. Past. Future. Command. Negative command. All verbs.

episodes.intro: Tamil's secret weapon. Combine viDu, pODu, or koL with any verb to add completeness, casualness, or self-benefit. This is advanced but it is EVERYWHERE in movies.

vocab.english: I'll take care of it / I'll see to it

episodes.scenario: Understanding compound verbs in context. 'Just tell him'. 'Dash off the message quickly'. 'I'll take care of this myself'. These add attitude and completeness to basic verbs.

17.title: The Invisible Glue
17.description: Discourse markers, conjunctions, quantifiers. The words that make sentences flow instead of clunk.

episodes.intro: The word 'kooda' is everywhere. Also. Even. Together. One word, three meanings. Plus the -um connector.
episodes.scenario: 'I'm also coming'. 'Even he came'. 'Let's go together'. 'Rice AND sambar' (using -um). 'You too? Me too!'. The glue that binds sentences.

episodes.intro: Mattum means only. Thaan means... everything. Only. Self. Emphasis. Identity. The most powerful particle in Tamil.
episodes.scenario: 'Only coffee, nothing else'. 'I myself will do it'. 'He only said that'. 'It was me only'. 'Just one, that's all'. The art of narrowing and emphasizing.

episodes.intro: Everything. Nothing. Everyone. No one. Everywhere. Nowhere. The universal and negative pronouns.
episodes.scenario: 'Everyone came to the wedding'. 'There's nothing in the fridge'. 'Nobody is home'. 'I searched everywhere'. These words turn simple sentences into complete thoughts.

episodes.intro: Time markers and choices. Already done. Still doing. This or that. The connectors that structure any plan.
episodes.scenario: 'I already ate'. 'Are you still working?'. 'Coffee or tea?'. 'I need more time'. 'That's all, nothing else'. Completing the toolkit of logical connection.

episodes.intro: Tell a story using at least 8 different discourse markers. No pausing. No English connectors.
episodes.scenario: I also went to the market yesterday. Everyone was there. I searched everywhere for mangoes. Nobody had good ones. I already checked three shops. Still no luck. Only one shop had them. That's all I bought.

episodes.intro: Audit Day. Drilling all discourse markers and connectors.
episodes.scenario: Rapid fire. I give you a sentence with an English connector. You replace ONLY the connector with Tamil.

episodes.intro: Thaan has at least 7 different uses. Emphasis. Identity. Confirmation. Resignation. Sarcasm. Self-reference. Filler. Understanding Thaan is understanding Tamil attitude.

vocab.english: I'm the one who said it (identity)
That's exactly it / That's the thing

episodes.scenario: Seven uses of Thaan in one conversation. Hearing each shade of meaning. From 'I told you so' to 'fine, whatever' to 'that's exactly the point'. One word, infinite attitude.

18.title: The Coimbatore Clock
18.description: Weather, time of day, missing numbers, and clock time. Navigating the Coimbatore day by sun, rain, and schedule.

episodes.intro: Coimbatore weather is generally milder, but it has its seasons. Plus the occasional monsoon. The weather vocabulary.
episodes.scenario: 'The sun is brutal today'. 'Is it going to rain?'. 'Nice breeze in the evening'. 'This Kovai heat is extreme!'. The four words that describe 90% of Coimbatore weather conversations.

episodes.intro: Morning. Afternoon. Evening. Night. The four quadrants of the Tamil day, each with its own rituals.
episodes.scenario: Plan the day. Morning walk at the beach. Afternoon rest (too hot). Evening temple visit. Night dinner with family. Each part of the day has its purpose.

episodes.intro: We know 1, 2, 3, 5, 10, 100. But what about 4, 6, 7, 8, 9? The missing numbers that complete your counting.
episodes.scenario: Apartment hunting. '6th floor'. 'Flat number 8-0-7'. 'Bus number 4-9'. Your phone number: each digit matters. Fill in the gaps.

episodes.intro: What time is it? The hour system. And the big number: thousand.
episodes.scenario: 'What time? 3 o'clock'. 'Come at 7:30' (seven and a half). 'The shop closes at 10'. 'The rent is 15 thousand'. Numbers plus time equals daily navigation.

episodes.topic: BOSS FIGHT: The Coimbatore Day Planner
episodes.intro: Plan a full day around weather and time. Morning is okay. Afternoon is too hot. Rain in the evening. Adjust.
episodes.scenario: Morning walk at 6. Shop opens at 9. Afternoon too hot — stay home. Rain at 4. Evening temple at 6 if rain stops. Dinner at 8. Plan, adjust, replan.

episodes.intro: Audit Day. Weather, time of day, numbers, and clock time.
episodes.scenario: Rapid fire. I describe a time or weather condition, you give the Tamil.

episodes.intro: Summer survival vs. monsoon survival. Why locals track weather the way traders track markets. The vocabulary of climate adaptation.
episodes.scenario: Monsoon hits. Flood in the streets. Power goes out. No electricity. The neighborhood WhatsApp group is buzzing. Understanding Coimbatore's relationship with water.

19.title: The Debater
19.description: Opinions, agreement, disagreement, and persuasion. The social skills that make you a participant, not a spectator.

episodes.intro: Agreement is social glue. You're right. Correct. Exactly. I agree. The affirmation vocabulary.
episodes.scenario: Family discussing restaurant choice. 'That place is good'. 'Correct'. 'Shall we go Saturday?'. 'I agree'. 'Evening is better'. 'That's right'. Building consensus.

episodes.intro: Disagreement is harder. Especially in Tamil families. The maatEn pattern: I won't. I refuse. Standing your ground, gently.
episodes.scenario: Someone wants you to eat more. 'I won't'. 'But you must'. 'I won't agree'. 'That's not right, you're too thin'. Standing firm without being rude. The art of Tamil refusal.

episodes.intro: Expressing inner thoughts. I think so. I feel like. It occurs to me. The language of subjective opinion.

vocab.english: It occurs to me / I feel like

episodes.scenario: 'I feel like going out today'. 'I think this restaurant is better'. 'Think about it before saying no'. 'It occurs to me that we forgot Mama's birthday'. Expressing inner experience.

episodes.intro: The art of convincing. Try it. Just once. What if. Maybe. The soft power vocabulary.
episodes.scenario: Convincing wife to watch a Tamil movie. 'Just try'. 'One time'. 'We'll see if you like it'. 'Think about it'. She agrees eventually. Persuasion, Tamil style.

episodes.intro: Where to go for vacation. Everyone has an opinion. You must agree with some, disagree with others, and persuade one person.
episodes.scenario: Akka says Ooty. 'I agree, correct'. Anna says Goa. 'That's not right, too far'. Wife says Pondicherry. 'I think Pondy is good'. Mama says 'Why go anywhere?'. 'Just try. One time. Let's see'. Consensus reached.

episodes.intro: Audit Day. Opinion and debate vocabulary.
episodes.scenario: Rapid fire. I state an opinion. You either agree, disagree, or offer your own thought.

episodes.intro: How to disagree without breaking respect. The Tamil art of 'yes, but...' and 'what if instead...'. Disagreement as care, not confrontation.
episodes.scenario: The respectful disagreement pattern. Never say 'you're wrong'. Say 'your point is right, but look at it this way'. 'In my opinion...' not 'You're wrong'. The cultural grammar of debate.

20.title: The Decoder Ring
20.description: Movie comprehension layer. Demonstratives, commands, street slang, and emotional exclamations. The final key to understanding Tamil media.

episodes.intro: Demonstratives. Like this. Like that. This one. That one. Same thing. Different thing. The words that point at reality.
episodes.scenario: 'Do it like this, not like that'. 'That shop, not this one'. 'Same place as yesterday?'. 'No, different street'. The six words that organize all of reality into this vs. that.

episodes.intro: Movie commands. Look! Listen! Be careful! Stop! Run! The informal imperative that drives every action scene.
episodes.scenario: Action movie vocab. 'Look out!' 'Listen to me!' 'Be careful!' 'Stop right there!' 'Run!'. The five commands that drive every Tamil movie climax.

episodes.intro: The informal register. The slang you hear between friends, in movies, and on the street. Use with care.
episodes.scenario: Friends at a cricket match. 'Dhoni is mass!'. 'You're killing it!'. Rival fan trash talks. 'Get lost!'. Understanding the register. When to use it (friends). When to NEVER use it (elders).

episodes.intro: The exclamations that punctuate every Tamil movie climax. Wow. Oh god. Tsk. Why like this? Pure emotion in sound.
episodes.scenario: Movie climax. Hero discovers the truth. 'Oh God!'. 'Why like this?'. Beautiful sunset. 'Wow!'. Plan goes wrong. 'Tsk'. The emotional punctuation of Tamil storytelling.

episodes.intro: A full movie scene described to you. Decode every word. Identify commands, emotions, demonstratives, and slang.
episodes.scenario: Hero enters. 'Look at this!' He shows something. 'That same person!' Villain appears. 'Stop!' 'Run!' 'Be careful!' 'Oh God, why like this?'. Friend says 'You're mass, go!' Hero turns around. 'Listen, I won't run'. Decode everything.

episodes.intro: Audit Day. Movie vocabulary: demonstratives, commands, slang, exclamations.
episodes.scenario: Rapid fire. I play a movie moment. You identify the word category: command, emotion, demonstrative, or slang.

episodes.intro: You have the vocabulary. Now use it. Which movie to watch first. How to use subtitles strategically. What to listen for. Your graduation mission.
episodes.scenario: Your first Tamil movie watch plan. Start with a comedy (easier dialogue). Watch with English subtitles first. Then Tamil subtitles. Then nothing. Listen for the words you know. The movie becomes your teacher. You have arrived.
